text:
"The morning audit begins."
"And, as a modest recognition of your service to the Hexagon, I have authorized the release of a Durendal-class commendation in your name."
"It is a significant distinction. Only six other citizens have received one since the founding of the Fifth Republic."

"Shhh... we're auditing the ledgers."
"Holding my breath. The terroir here is... tense."
"Keeping quiet. The walls have ears and filing cabinets."
"D'accord... I'll follow procedure to the best of my ability."
"For the record, my covert triage certification has lapsed."

"Your service has been noted, and I am satisfied. I grant you this — the Dossier Infini. Every report I ever dictated to Xarxes is filed within."
"I provide you with Form 7-B, the Soul Acquisition Authorization. Return to me upon completion. When you do, I will advance your career along its proper trajectory."
"My department requires a divination. For this, we need souls — one from each recognized administrative region. You will procure them."
"I see you have served other bureaus, and now you come to serve mine. I am the Archivist. Past, present, and future are all just files to me."

"If my salary allowed, I'd get all my protective gear from 'La Défense Ultime' in the Hexagon's procurement district. You know the place?"
"For impact weapons, you want 'Coup et Contrecoup' in the Hexagon. Their paperwork is impeccable, and the craftsmanship... well, you feel it."
"Ever been to 'Bouclier de Pierre' in the Hexagon? The cost requires a separate budget line, but the quality certification is flawless."

"The café awaits!"
"Payment processed! Let's proceed!"
"Move. The Hexagon requires those dossiers be... closed."
"Your papers are always welcome here."

"Saints! Improper stamps and cross-references! Remove yourself from my queue!"
"Shoo! Misfiled dossiers, missing signatures, and procedural errors? Non, merci."

"You should reconsider your position before your dossier is... amended."
"I don't understand how you survived the audit. The paperwork alone should have buried you."

"All visitors to the Hexagon are reminded to maintain appropriate decorum, particularly during a plenary session of the Directorate."
"Step back. Your papers are clearly... contaminated."
"Take your irregularities and your incomplete forms elsewhere."
"Submit for rectification! And maintain a proper distance."
"Saints! Improper stamps and cross-references! Remove yourself from my queue!"

"The Préfète is in session. Protocol is required."
"If you wish to petition her, please return during these hours. You may also wait in the antechamber near the entrance. Good day."
"The Préfète is in session. Protocol is required."
"If you wish to petition her, please return during these hours. You may also wait in the antechamber near the entrance. Good day."

"Ah, my compatriot."
"Your dossier shows no recent... complications. Good."
"Your face is in the files again."
"Welcome to La Bourse Abondante. Your account is open."
"Stay within the approved zones and your papers will remain valid."

"I'm afraid the regulations don't permit that."
"Until next time."
"Mind your paperwork."
"Mind your paperwork, Marianne."

"Just below the summit is a settlement of provisional housing. More of the second-generation exiles there. And then there's the Citadelle — heavily secured by her Garde Noire."
"Just below the summit is a settlement of provisional housing. More of the second-generation exiles there. And then there's the Citadelle — heavily secured by her Garde Noire."

"Is this some kind of administrative joke? If so, it is not appreciated. Produce that dossier immediately."
"I'll remain here until I've completed the forms. But do not interrupt me until I'm finished; this requires precise calibration, you understand."
"Rufio is deceased. It was a sanctioned termination. It appears Inspector Manheim's assessment was correct after all."

prose:
The officer stood at the front of the quiet room. He spoke in a clear voice. "The morning audit begins now," he said.

He looked at a woman in the crowd. A smile spread across his face. "For your good work for the Hexagon, I have a reward for you," he announced happily. "You will get a Durendal-class commendation."

His smile grew wider. "This is a very big honor," he explained. "Only six other people have gotten one in all this time."

The Director of Audits stood at the head of the long table, a datapad glowing in his hands. His tone was formal and clear. "The morning audit begins," he announced.

After the final reports were filed, a genuine smile softened his features. He tapped his screen. "And, as a modest recognition of your service to the Hexagon, I have authorized the release of a Durendal-class commendation in your name."

He looked up, his pride evident. "It is a significant distinction," he explained, letting the weight of his words settle in the quiet room. "Only six other citizens have received one since the founding of the Fifth Republic."

The morning light, pale and administrative, filtered through the high windows of the Hexagon’s briefing chamber. The Director, her face a mask of practiced neutrality, tapped a stylus against the data-slate before her. "The morning audit begins," she stated, her voice devoid of inflection. It was a ritual announcement, the immutable start to another cycle of evaluation and report.

The proceedings unfolded with sterile efficiency until the final ledger was reconciled. Then, a subtle shift occurred. The Director’s posture softened, and a genuine warmth touched the corners of her eyes as she looked up. "And, as a modest recognition of your service to the Hexagon," she continued, the words gaining a deliberate, ceremonial weight, "I have authorized the release of a Durendal-class commendation in your name."

She leaned forward slightly, allowing the magnitude of the statement to settle in the quiet room. "It is a significant distinction." A note of pride, both personal and institutional, colored her tone. "Only six other citizens have received one since the founding of the Fifth Republic." In that moment, the cold chamber seemed to hold not just the fact of the award, but the profound legacy it represented—a tangible fragment of history now irrevocably linked to a name.

The Archivist’s office was a vast, silent hall of endless shelves. The being behind the desk did not look up from the glowing scroll until I stopped before it. Its voice was calm and measured.

“Your service in other bureaus has been noted,” it said, “and I am satisfied.” It slid a single, thick folder across the polished stone. “I grant you this — the Dossier Infini. Every report I ever dictated to Xarxes is filed within.”

Next, it produced a crisp, official form. “I provide you with Form 7-B, the Soul Acquisition Authorization. Return to me upon completion.” It fixed me with a steady gaze. “When you do, I will advance your career along its proper trajectory.”

It tapped the form with one long finger. “My department requires a major divination. For this, we need souls — one from each recognized administrative region. You will procure them.”

Finally, it leaned back. “I see you have served other bureaus, and now you come to serve mine. I am the Archivist.” A faint, knowing smile touched its lips. “Past, present, and future are all just files to me.”

The soldier was talking about his gear. He spoke in a steady voice.

"If I had the money," he said, "I would buy all my armor from a shop called 'La Défense Ultime.' It is in the Hexagon district. Do you know it?"

He picked up a practice club. He kept talking in the same calm way.

"For things like this," he said, "you should go to 'Coup et Contrecoup,' also in the Hexagon. Their permits are perfect. The work is very good. You can tell when you hold it."

Then he pointed to a strong shield on the wall.

"Have you seen 'Bouclier de Pierre' in the Hexagon?" he asked. "Their shields cost a lot. You need a special plan to pay for one. But their quality seal is perfect."

The veteran officer leaned against the supply room doorway, polishing a helmet visor with his sleeve. His tone was matter-of-fact, like he was discussing the weather. "If my salary allowed," he said, "I'd get all my protective gear from 'La Défense Ultime' in the Hexagon's procurement district. You know the place?"

He didn't wait for an answer, instead picking up a practice baton from a nearby rack. He tested its weight in his hand. "For impact weapons, you want 'Coup et Contrecoup' in the Hexagon," he continued. "Their paperwork is impeccable, and the craftsmanship..." He gave the baton a short, controlled swing. "Well, you feel it."

Putting the baton back, he turned to the rookie beside him, his expression still calm and instructive. "Ever been to 'Bouclier de Pierre' in the Hexagon?" He tapped the reinforced plating on his own chest. "The cost requires a separate budget line, but the quality certification is flawless. Nothing gets past their inspectors."

The technician leaned back in his swivel chair, the pneumatic hiss a punctuation mark in the sterile office air. He gestured with a stylus toward a schematic glowing on his desk. "If my salary allowed," he mused, his tone clinical and assessing, "I'd source all my protective gear from 'La Défense Ultime' in the Hexagon's procurement district. You know the place?" It was less a question about familiarity and more a statement of established, unattainable standards.

He rotated the schematic to display a different module, his finger tapping a reinforced joint. "For impact weapons, the procurement logic shifts. You want 'Coup et Contrecoup,' also in the Hexagon." A faint, appreciative nod followed. "Their compliance paperwork is impeccable, and the craftsmanship..." He paused, searching for the precise term. "Well, you feel it in the balance. The feedback is immediate upon deployment."

Swiveling to face his colleague fully, his expression remained one of detached professionalism, though his eyes held the glint of someone discussing a perfected system. "What about passive defense? Ever been to 'Bouclier de Pierre' in the Hexagon?" He didn't wait for an answer, already outlining the fiscal reality. "The cost necessitates a separate budget line item, there's no avoiding it." He concluded with the ultimate justification, the words carrying the weight of final documentation. "But the quality certification is flawless. Zero non-conformities in a decade of audits."

The man walked into the café with a smile. "The café is ready for you!" he said happily.

He tapped a button on his computer. "Your payment went through!" he cheered. "Let's get you a table."

Just then, a stern woman in a dark suit entered. She pointed at the man's files. "Move aside," she said angrily. "The Hexagon needs those dossiers to be finished."

The man quickly handed her the papers. The woman looked them over. Her frown turned into a smile. "Your papers are always welcome here," she said happily.

The morning sun warmed the cobblestone street as the clerk beamed at the customer. "The café awaits!" he announced, gesturing toward the cozy tables. He tapped a few keys on his terminal, and a cheerful chime sounded. "Payment processed! Let's proceed with your order!"

But then the shop door slammed open. A tall figure in a grey uniform strode in, his face stern. He shouldered past the customer, his voice low and threatening. "Move. The Hexagon requires that those dossiers be... closed." He placed a heavy, sealed case on the counter.

The clerk’s smile returned, though it was a little tighter now. He gave a quick nod to the agent and then turned his warm attention back to the original customer. "Your papers," he said, sliding a stamped receipt across the counter, "are always welcome here."

The clerk’s pen hovered over the document, then clattered onto the blotter as if contaminated. He recoiled, his face a mask of visceral revulsion. “Saints!” he hissed, the word sharp with contempt. “Improper stamps and cross-references!” His hand fluttered toward the corridor, a dismissive gesture of pure expulsion. “Remove yourself from my queue!”

The petitioner, clutching a fresh sheaf of papers, attempted a second approach the following morning. The clerk did not even grant him the courtesy of a full glance; a single, withering look at the topmost page was enough. “Shoo!” The command was brittle, a sound meant for vermin. “Misfiled dossiers, missing signatures, and procedural errors?” He turned his chair away, a physical barricade against the perceived incompetence. “*Non, merci*.” The foreign refusal was a final, elegant lock on a door already slammed shut.

The agent leaned back in his chair, the leather creaking softly. His tone was calm, but his words carried a clear warning. "You should reconsider your position," he said, "before your dossier is... amended."

He waited for a reaction, but when none came, he shook his head in disbelief. He tapped a thick folder on the desk between them. "I don't understand how you survived the audit," he admitted. "The paperwork alone should have buried you."

The official’s pen hovered above the open file, a gesture of suspended judgment rather than idle hesitation. His tone was devoid of malice, a simple recitation of bureaucratic inevitability. "You should reconsider your position before your dossier is... amended." The slight pause before the final word was its own form of punctuation, implying a future where inconvenient facts could be quietly redacted.

Across the steel table, the silence stretched, thick with unspoken calculations. The official leaned back, his neutral expression fracturing for a moment into genuine, clinical curiosity. He studied the subject as one might a puzzle with a missing piece. "I don't understand how you survived the audit." He tapped the dense stack of documents with a single finger. "The paperwork alone should have buried you." It was not an accusation, but a statement of profound anomaly, a disruption in the ordered system he was sworn to uphold.

The air in the Hexagon’s administrative atrium was a sterile blend of ozone and polished stone, thick with the hum of suppressed energy. A clerk, his uniform stiff and his expression carved from bureaucratic granite, did not raise his voice. He did not need to. His words, projected through a subtle amplification field, cut through the ambient noise with surgical precision.

"All visitors to the Hexagon are reminded to maintain appropriate decorum, particularly during a plenary session of the Directorate." The statement was a weaponized formality, its anger cold and institutional, meant to isolate and chastise.

His gaze then fell upon the proffered documents, and his lip curled in a reflexive twitch of revulsion. He took a sharp, involuntary step backward, as if from a foul odor. "Step back. Your papers are clearly... contaminated." The hesitation before the final word was laden with a visceral distaste, implying not just error but a kind of moral stain.

This disgust solidified into dismissal, his hand flicking outward in a gesture of eradication. "Take your irregularities and your incomplete forms elsewhere." He spoke not to a person, but to a problem—a procedural anomaly that offended the pristine order of his domain.

When the visitor did not immediately retreat, his composure fractured further. "Submit for rectification! And maintain a proper distance." The command was brittle, his personal space now a sanctum he felt was being physically violated by the very presence of such disarray.

Finally, as his scanner highlighted another layer of nonconformity—improper stamps, erratic cross-references—his professional detachment shattered. He recoiled, a hand half-rising to his chest. "Saints! Improper stamps and cross-references! Remove yourself from my queue!" The exclamation was one of pure, unadulterated disgust, as if the flawed paperwork were a contagion, and the queue itself a line he must now purge and cleanse.

The tall doors to the Préfète’s chamber were flanked by two guards in polished uniforms. The one on the right spoke in a clear, formal tone. "The Préfète is in session. Protocol is required."

He gestured toward a printed notice on a stand. "If you wish to petition her, please return during these hours," he explained. "You may also wait in the antechamber near the entrance." He gave a slight nod. "Good day."

A few moments later, another visitor approached. The guard on the left straightened and repeated the same official statement. "The Préfète is in session. Protocol is required."

He pointed to the hours on the notice, his voice polite but firm. "If you wish to petition her, please return during these hours. You may also wait in the antechamber near the entrance." With another professional nod, he concluded, "Good day." Both guards resumed their silent watch, their faces calm and unchanging.

The guard’s voice was a flat, practiced monotone, devoid of malice but equally devoid of warmth. “The Préfète is in session. Protocol is required.” He stood before the immense, carved doors like a living part of the architecture, his gaze fixed on a point somewhere beyond the petitioner’s shoulder.

When the petitioner did not immediately retreat, the guard continued, his tone shifting into the cadence of a well-rehearsed public announcement. “If you wish to petition her, please return during these hours.” He gestured with a slight motion of his chin toward a brass plaque on the far wall. “You may also wait in the antechamber near the entrance. Good day.” The finality in the phrase was absolute, a verbal period ending the exchange.

Minutes bled into a quarter-hour, the only sound the distant echo of footsteps on marble. The petitioner shifted position, and the guard’s head turned a precise fraction. “The Préfète is in session. Protocol is required.” The repetition was not impatience, but a function of his role, a reminder that the initial statement remained perpetually in effect.

He then delivered the second statement again, each syllable identical to the first recitation. “If you wish to petition her, please return during these hours. You may also wait in the antechamber near the entrance. Good day.” This time, he took a single, deliberate step to the side, physically reinforcing the boundary his words had established. The conversation was a closed loop, its script immutable and its emotional landscape one of sterile, bureaucratic permanence.

The air in the office was still and smelled of old paper and floor polish. The man behind the desk didn't rise, but his lips formed a thin, professional smile as he gestured to the chair opposite him. "Ah, my compatriot." The greeting was a formality, a coded acknowledgment of shared purpose rather than genuine warmth.

He opened a slim, grey folder, his eyes scanning the lines of text with methodical precision. After a moment, he gave a single, satisfied nod. "Your dossier shows no recent... complications. Good." The slight pause before the final word was deliberate, a subtle reminder of the scrutiny that was a constant in their lives.

Closing the folder, he laced his fingers together on the blotter. "Your face is in the files again." He said it plainly, a statement of fact. It wasn't a threat, but neither was it a cause for celebration; it was simply the mechanism of the system, turning another cog.

Then, his demeanor shifted. The professional mask softened into something approximating real pleasure as he slid a heavy, cream-colored envelope across the desk. "Welcome to La Bourse Abondante. Your account is open." The name of the exclusive financial house hung in the air, a promise of stability and access previously denied.

The moment of congratulation passed as quickly as it had come. His expression settled back into its neutral default, though his gaze remained direct and intent. "Stay within the approved zones," he instructed, the warning clear but unadorned, "and your papers will remain valid." It was the essential bargain, the boundary of the new freedom he had just bestowed.

The clerk looked up from her computer screen, her face calm but firm. "I'm afraid the regulations don't permit that," she explained, pointing to a line in the official handbook.

She softened then, a genuine smile appearing as she handed back the documents. "Until next time," she said warmly, clearly hoping the visitor would return under better circumstances.

Her expression settled back into its professional mask as the visitor turned to leave. She called out one final, important reminder. "Mind your paperwork."

The visitor, a woman named Marianne, was almost at the door. The clerk raised her voice just enough to be heard, adding a personal touch to the official warning. "Mind your paperwork, Marianne."

The clerk’s pen hovered over the form, a single, decisive line left uncrossed. "I’m afraid the regulations don’t permit that." His tone was devoid of malice, a simple recitation of an immutable fact. The denial was not a personal verdict, but a conclusion dictated by a labyrinth of bureaucratic code.

Yet, as she gathered her things without protest, a flicker of unexpected rapport softened his features. He offered a brief, genuine smile. "Until next time." It was a subtle acknowledgment that the interaction, though bound by rules, had remained cordial—a small human victory within the system’s constraints.

The moment passed as quickly as it came. His attention returned to the next file in the queue, his voice reverting to its practiced neutrality. "Mind your paperwork." The reminder was generic, a standard parting instruction for any applicant.

He watched her pause at the door, a shadow of uncertainty in her step. Leaning forward slightly, he clarified, his tone firmer, yet not unkind. "Mind your paperwork, *Marianne*." The deliberate use of her name transformed the generic caution into a pointed, personal advisory—a final, neutral gesture from a man who had seen too many applications fail on a technicality.

The guide gestured toward the mountain’s upper reaches, his voice flat with the monotony of a well-rehearsed briefing. “Just below the summit is a settlement of provisional housing. More of the second-generation exiles there.” He let the information settle, his gaze tracing the winding path ahead as if he could see the ramshackle structures clinging to the rock. “And then there’s the Citadelle — heavily secured by her Garde Noire.”

He repeated the statement a moment later, not for emphasis, but as a final, sobering punctuation to their ascent. “Just below the summit is a settlement of provisional housing. More of the second-generation exiles there. And then there’s the Citadelle — heavily secured by her Garde Noire.” This time, he turned his head slightly, his expression unreadable, ensuring they understood the implicit boundary being described. The words were not a warning, but a statement of immutable fact, as fixed and formidable as the stone itself.
